medium: Ink and light color on paper
title: Moonlit Scene
text: The Kan' school of influential painters working for the shogunate was one of the most important Japanese painting schools for the landscape genre. They were responsible for decorating the residences and castles of affluent and high-ranking samurai. Sansetsu headed the branch in Kyoto while Tan'yu (1602'74) lead the Edo branch. By the beginning of the Edo period (1603'1868), the Kan' painters turned to a more subdued, refined style that coincided with a renewed interest in monochrome ink painting.
creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture; formerly acquired by the Center with the kind assistance of Carol Brooks and Prof. James Cahill in honor of George Schlenker
